title: Normani & Two-Time Olympian Jordan Chiles Switch Roles In New ‘Switching Stages’ Episode
summary: The Olympic athlete and music powerhouse take a walk in each other's shoes in the latest episode.
body: In the second episode of Billboard and The Players’ Tribune’s video series Switching Stages, Normani and Two-Time Olympian Jordan Chiles take turns stepping into each other’s shoes for the day. Normani is no stranger to gymnastics, so had the opportunity to perform sophisticated cartwheels and aerials on the beam while Jordan helped her utilize some expert-level technique and form. Elsewhere, the pair stepped into Normani’s world, and learned some tight choreography to Normani’s song “All Yours.” “I actually feel inspired to continue to get back into the gym,” Normani told Jordan after their afternoon together. “You actually inspired me to start dancing,” Jordan replied before going in for a high five. The second episode of Switching Stages comes after Atlanta Hawks point guard Trae Young and Grammy-nominated rapper Quavo spent some time sharing nostalgic stories of growing up in Atlanta. title: How Toronto Became the Epicenter of Music & Culture During Blue Jays’ World Series Run
summary: From Drake to Justin Bieber, Jonas Brothers to Geddy Lee, the city became a global hub for baseball, music & culture during the 2025 World Series.
body: If Canadian music sounds a little bit sadder over the next year, there’s a good reason: Across the country, fans are grappling with the heartbreak of a painful World Series loss. In Toronto, where fans of all stripes tuned in, the city is feeling the weight. Related Drake Supports Hometown Blue Jays at Game 6 of the World Series Justin Bieber Watches as Dodgers Edge Blue Jays in Historic World Series Game L.A. Dodgers Troll Drake With Kendrick Lamar Lyrics After Toronto Blue Jays Lose World Series For one glorious week, the city became the epicenter of not just sports, but culture. As the Toronto Blue Jays played the Los Angeles Dodgers for baseball’s biggest prize, the game emanated not just from the Rogers Centre, but homes, bars and even music venues. It wasn’t just that Toronto was watching baseball. Baseball became part of the city’s cultural rhythm, blurring the lines between the game and the music that soundtracks it. In that moment, baseball became a mirror for Canadian culture — uniting generations, artists and genres around a team that felt bigger than the city it played for. For bands who had shows on the night of the pivotal Game 7 on Saturday nigh…

title: 10 Songs Lainey Wilson Wrote for Other Artists
summary: Lainey Wilson is known for her own hits such as "Heart Like a Truck" and "4x4xU," but she's also co-written songs recorded by other artists.
body: Lainey Wilson continues to amass an array of impressive career accolades as an artist and entertainer, including trophies from the Academy of Country Music, Country Music Association, and the Recording Academy. She’s one of the most-nominated artists leading into this year’s CMA Awards, where she’s vying again for the coveted entertainer of the year title. A testament to her onstage poise and charisma, the Louisiana native will also solo host the CMA Awards this year. She previously won the CMA’s entertainer of the year honor in 2023, and has taken home the ACM’s entertainer of the year accolade in 2024 and 2025. She’s spearheaded her headlining Whirlwind arena tour, and has had both her own Billboard Country Airplay chart hits with “Heart Like a Truck,” “Things a Man Oughta Know” and “Watermelon Moonshine,” as well as the collaborative hits “Save Me” (with Jelly Roll) and “Never Say Never” (with Cole Swindell). summary: "I haven’t seen him for a long time now, ‘cause it’s too much," the Swedish rapper said in a new interview.
body: Yung Lean spoke about his relationship with Ye (formerly Kanye West ) and Travis Scott in a new interview with The New York Times Popcast . title: Ice Spice Uses ‘Pretty Privilege’ to Her Advantage in Fashion-Forward Music Video
summary: She follows up the release of her "Baddie Baddie" track with a new single.
body: Six weeks after releasing her “Baddie Baddie” track , Ice Spice returned on Wednesday (Nov. 5) with “Pretty Privilege,” which could signal that her Y2K! follow-up isn’t far away in 2026. Ice reunites with frequent collaborator RIOTUSA on the production side for the trippy drill-leaning tune. The Bronx native cycles through her typical themes as she addresses the haters, flaunts her looks, deep pockets and how you’ll never hit. “Pretty Privilege, that’s a perk/ I can’t help it, I’m a flirt/ Fine s—t, that’s a fact/ From the front, you see the back/ PR said no clappin’ back, mwah,” she raps to close out the track. Ice Spice also released an accompanying lavish visual for “Pretty Privilege,” and the rapper’s wardrobe didn’t disappoint in the fashion-forward video. Switching into a pink bob wig, Ice twerks on a balcony and then brings out a white couture dress as she flexes in front of her suburban mansion tucked away in the woods. While Ice remained quiet throughout much of 2025’s first half, the 25-year-old is gaining some momentum in quarter four. Between “Baddie Baddie…
